title: Armor feeling underwhelming?
body:

People here aren't saying it clearly... but I can help lay it out some.  I put a lot of work into figuring out some of this for runes for my own build and found out one useful bit of information:

Armor in LoL doesn't give a flat bonus.  It actually reduces the amount of damage you take based off your HEALTH and ARMOR.  Building armor is great, but unless you are building health too at a rate of (personal estimate here, but seems to be good) of about 750-1000 health per 100 armor.  It also helps to build up mana and MR because you can build {{item:3075}}, {{item:3065}}, {{item:3110}} and {{item:3083}} and end up tanky as hell.  If the enemy gets a bunch of armor pen that is making you take more damage then focus on health and not armor.

Since armor is based off health you NEED to keep a high health with it, armor alone will not help.  Using armor alone is why people complain tanks melt.  Build a ton of armor and HP and you will be really tanky.

Edit: http://leagueoflegends.wikia.com/wiki/Armor for more information

The defensive bonus from armor is not based off health.  100 armor on Lux and 100 armor on Malphite provide the same amount of physical damage reduction.  However, damage reduction has amazing synergy with health, and so it is a good idea to get health and armor/mr

for example (with nice numbers)

A champ with 1000 health takes 10 hits to kill (each dealing 100 damage).  A champ with 1000 health and 25% reduction in damage from armor takes 14 hits to kill (each effectively doing 75 damage due to the resistance).  A champ with 2000 health would take 20 hits.  A champ with 2000 health and 25% reduction would take 27 hits.  In order to match this number, a champ with 1000 health would need about 67% reduction.  Due to the way armor scales, it takes a lot more armor to get to that point.

Thus, resistance is better with higher HP because it takes more hits to deal enough damage to kill you.

Well, I'm not sure where all the information you got is from, but I got mine here: http://leagueoflegends.wikia.com/wiki/Armor which has the same formula that I find on any other site.

I did word it wrong a little bit, but I was trying to get the point across.  If you take reduced damage then it takes more damage to kill you: that means you have a higher effective health.  Increasing only one without the other doesn't lead to an efficient effective health, so it's not all too inaccurate to say that the benefit you get from armor is based off the relationship between your armor and health.

I based my analysis on math - the relationship between damage reduction and health, as a purely hypothetical situation with the given stats.  Because the reduction from armor/MR is not linear, I didn't base my analysis on numbers from in-game to keep things simple.

Armor/MR is not reliant on health, but your survivability (and therefore tankiness) is dependent on both.

Every single point in Armor or Magic Resist is as effective as the last. 1 point in either stat raises your Effective Health to that kind of damage by 1%.

What this means:
If you have 1000 health and 100 armor it takes 2000 physical damage to kill you
If you have 1000 health and 200 armor it takes 3000 physical damage to kill you
If you have 1000 health and 300 armor it takes 4000  physical damage and so on.

A tank with 3000 health and 200 armor requires 9000 physical damage to kill. The 9000 is your effective health against that damage type.

You need to properly balance your health and armor purchases to get the most gold and slot efficiency since health and resists work multiplicatively together.

This is all assuming no penetration for the purpose of explaining the concept.

Yes, but that wasn't my point.  I was talking about the effect of damage reduction and health - which armor and MR provides.  Each point of armor/MR does not provide the same amount of damage reduction, but because the equation yields a percentage-based damage resistance, each point does ends up providing the same increase in effective health.

My issue was with the specific wording that the defenses from armor are based on your heath, which is not true.  100 armor works the same for any champ, regardless of how much HP they have - it provides the same amount of damage reduction.  Now, the damage reduction works a lot better with champs that have more health, as noted and agreed upon, as it allows them to take more hits.

That is not now, and never has been true.  Every single point of armor gives the exact same amount of survivability:  1% of your maximum HP.

In this case, assuming you somehow had 1000 HP for less complicated math, at 300 armor you would have 4000 effective HP, 540 armor would bump that up to 6400 effective HP, a far greater difference than the apparent ~10% difference in damage reduction would suggest.  Of course, % penetration heavily depreciates the value of the stats (and is also too prevalent right now) and there are all sorts of variables involved, but armor is mathematically a linear survivability boost, not a diminishing curve.

You're right about one thing though, the value of health increases drastically as you acquire more armor (and vice versa) so you need both to reach decent levels of tankiness.

Because you aren't doing math. You're using a representative value to gauge the true value of a statistic. 

Think about it this way:

As far as damage reduction goes, 0-100% is not as 'small' as it seems. Its not just 0 to 100. Its 0 to infinity. You are using the values 0 to 100 to represent 0 to infinity, which is not really accurate. If you look at the actual values, which is +1% total health vs physical damage per point of armor, its linear. Entirely linear, and based off of the amount of health you have.

1 point of armor is +1% effective health vs physical damage. 2 points of armor is +2% effective health vs physical damage. This continues on even past 1000, where 1000 points of armor is +1000% effective health vs physical damage. 

That is called linear scaling. 

__________

Also, if you have 0 armor, +%10 reduction means you are taking .9 of the damage you would take (100 x .9=90 damage). If you are at 50% reduction, +10% reduction is actually .8 of the damage you would have taken prior (100 x .5=50 damage-> 100 x .6 is 40 damage, which is 80% of the value of 50). Yeah, each % of reduction is twice as hard to get, but it also has twice the effect. After 66% reduction, it is then three times as hard to get, but 3 times as effective. 75%+ is 4 times as hard to get, but 4 times as effective. At 80%+, a 1% increase in damage reduction is 5 times as hard to get, but each 1% increase is 5x as effective. 

Each 100 armor brings you up one 'tier', in that regard. 0=0% reduction (100% EHP). 100=50% reduction (200% EHP). 200=66% reduction (300% EHP). 300=75% reduction (400% EHP). 400=80% reduction (500% EHP). 

This is the damage reduction that your EHP represents. Notice how you get the exact same increase in EHP per point of armor, even though it appears that your damage reduction is increasing by less. 

It is, in fact, linear. Not diminishing. 

_________

What you're thinking of is % increase of your total EHP. Normally you have 100% effective health as a base. 10 armor makes that 110% effective health vs physical damage. To increase this by another 10%, you would have to purchase 11 points of armor, leaving you at 121% EHP. To increase by another 10%, you'd need 12 more points of armor, so on and so forth. 

If you have 5 apples and buy another 5 (+100%), that doesn't mean you have to then buy 10 (+100%) to get the same value. Each apple is still worth just as much as the next. You using % values to measure your increase in apples doesn't somehow make each apple worth less just because it doesn't provide as much of a boost to your % apple intake with each flat increase in apples you make in purchases.
